case_name: Life Insurance Corporation v. V. V. Oak and S. V. Oak

facts.text: This is an appeal by certificate against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated July 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated July 29, 1960 in a petition under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution reversing the decision of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur dated December 30, 1959.

facts.text: The proceedings arose from the taking over of the controlled business of the Continental Mutual Assurance Company Ltd., Poona by the Life Insurance Corporation under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 (31 of 1956).

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings arose from the taking over of the companytrolled business of the Continental Mutual Assurance Company Ltd., Poona by the Life Insurance Corporation under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956  31 of 1956 .

facts.text: The Insurance Company was a mutual Company and thus had no share capital.

anchor.surface_text: The Insurance Company was a mutual Company and thus had numbershare capital.

facts.text: The respondents V. V. Oak and S. V. Oak had made five deposits totaling Rs. 7,408.81P. in the last weeks of December 1950 and 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It received deposits from Directors and other persons and the respondents V. V. Oak and S. V. Oak bad made five deposits totaling- Rs. 7,408.81P. in the last weeks of December 1950 and 1951.

facts.text: These deposits carried interest at 4-1/2 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: These deposits carried interest at 4-1/2 per annum.

facts.text: The Insurance Company was incorporated in 1946 and carried on only life insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: The Insurance Company was incorporated in 1946 and carried on only life insurance business.

facts.text: The first valuation was of the business as on December 31, 1950 and it showed a loss of Rs. 72,924.

anchor.surface_text: The first valuation was of the business as on December 31, 1950 and it showed a loss of Rs. 72,924 and its balance-sheet showed some assets totaling Rs. 11,216, which were perhaps number realizable.

facts.text: The certificate of registration of the Insurance Company was cancelled in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate of registration of the Insurance Company was cancelled in 1952 and the Controller of Insurance threatened to wind up the Insurance Company if the insolvency was number removed.

facts.text: In July 1952, all the Directors of the Insurance Company addressed a letter to the Controller guaranteeing to make good the deficit before the end of October of that year.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1952, all the Directors of. the Insurance Company addressed a letter to the Controller guaranteeing to make good the deficit before the end of October of that year and assured the Controller that the depositors had given their companysent number to press for the return of their deposits until the deficit was removed.

facts.text: The Controller then revived the certificate of registration but as the deficit was not removed before the end of October, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller then revived the certificate of registration but as the deficit was number removed before the end of October, 1952 the Chairman of the Insurance Company informed the Controller that immovable property of the value of Rs. 49,000 from the deposits was being purchased

facts.text: Copy of letter dated 7th November 1952 from the Assistant Controller of Insurance to the Company stating deposits to be repaid only out of future valuation surpluses.

anchor.surface_text: Copy of letter dated 7th November 1952 from the Assistant Controller of Insurance to the Company. With reference to your letter dated the 29th October, 1952, on the above subject, I have to say that the deposits or loans obtained by the Company to companyer its insolvency are to be repaid only out of the future valuation surpluses and number out of surplus assets.

facts.text: Copy of letter dated 29th November 1952, from V. V. Oak, the 1st Respondent to the Company giving consent to keep deposit repayable only out of adequate surplus.

anchor.surface_text: Copy of letter dated 29th November 1952, from V. V. Oak, the 1st Respondent to the Company. I hereby give my companysent to keep the amount of my deposit of Rs. 7,408-0-0  Rupees Seven thousand four hundred and eight only , with the companypany and that the same is repayable only out of adequate surplus along with interest thereon, as from the date of the last valuation,

facts.text: This undertaking was given by V. V. Oak on behalf of his son S. V. Oak also.

anchor.surface_text: This undertaking was given by V. V. Oak on behalf of his son S. V. Oak also.

facts.text: The actuarial valuation as on December 31, 1954 disclosed a deficit of Rs. 89,923.

anchor.surface_text: The actuarial valuation as on December 31, 1954 disclosed a deficit of Rs. 89,923 and before the next actuarial valuation the Life Insurance Corporation Act came into operation.

facts.text: Under the Life Insurance Emergency Provisions Ordinance, 1956, the business of the Insurance Company had been taken over by the Government of India on January 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Even before that under the Life Insurance  Emergency Provisions  Ordinance, 1956  which was followed by Act 9 of 1956 of the same name , the business of the Insurance Company had been taken over by the Government of India on January 19, 1956.

facts.text: On the passing of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, the controlled business of all insurers vested on September 1, 1956 in the Life Insurance Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: On the passing of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, the companytrolled business of all insurers vested on September 1, 1956 in the Life Insurance Corporation.

facts.text: The respondents after serving a notice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure filed a suit in the Bombay City Civil Court on January 5, 1959 (Suit No. 149 of 1959).

anchor.surface_text: The respondents after serving a numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure filed a suit in the Bombay City Civil Court on January 5, 1959  Suit No. 149 of 1959 . That suit, we are, informed is still pending.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation filed a petition on October 5, 1959 before the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur (Case No. 31/XII of 1959).

anchor.surface_text: Me Life Insurance-Corporation, on the other hand, filed a petition on October 5, 1959 before the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur praying for a declaration that the respondents were number entitled to the repayment of their deposits,

facts.text: The Tribunal, by its Order dated December 30, 1959 held that the amount was not repayable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, by its Order dated December 30, 1959  Case No. 31/XII of 1959 , held that the amount was number repayable.

facts.text: Against the decision of the Tribunal the depositors filed a petition under Articles 226 and 227 in the High Court of Bombay (Special Civil Application No. 279 of 1960) disposed on July 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the Tribunal the depositors filed a petition under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution  Special Civil Application No. 279 of 1960  in the High Court of Bombay. The petition was disposed of on July 29, 1960 by the order of the High Court,

facts.text: The High Court reversed the decision of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decision of the Tribunal.

facts.text: The Insurance Company from the point of view of the Insurance Act was insolvent when it was taken over.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the Insurance Company from the point of view of the Insurance Act was insolvent when it was taken over.

facts.text: The working of the Corporation showed an enormous valuation surplus.

anchor.surface_text: The working of the Corporation showed an enormous valuation surplus and the respondents claimed that as the Condition on which their deposits were held bad been fulfilled,

facts.text: The Divisional Bench held that the intention of the Life Insurance Corporation Act was to take over the controlled business as it was, of an insurer and to realise all assets and to pay all liabilities arising from contracts related to the controlled business.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench held that the intention of the Life Insurance Corporation Act was to take over the companytrolled business as it was, of an insurer and to realise all assets and to pay all liabilities arising from companytracts related to the companytrolled business.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the contracts were binding upon the Corporation as on the Insurance Company.

anchor.surface_text: The companytracts were, therefore, binding upon the Corporation as on the Insurance Company and, in fact, as if the Corporation itself had undertaken the liability.

issues.text: Whether the two sections, Section 9 and Section 28 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, must be read harmoniously such that Section 28 does not negate the obligations under Section 9?

anchor.surface_text: The two sections must be read harmoniously and it could not have been intended that s. 28 was to be used to negative what s. 9 provided so explicitly.

arguments.claim: s.9 and s.28 read harmoniously; s.28 discretionary does not negate s.9 obligations

anchor.surface_text: The two sections must be read harmoniously and it could not have been intended that s. 28 was to be used to negative what s. 9 provided so explicitly.

holdings.text: The deposit contracts subsisted as contingent liabilities on the date of vesting and were transferred to and binding upon the Life Insurance Corporation under Section 9 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is wrong to contend that as the Insurance Company had nosurplus in its hand on September 1, 1956, its contingent liabilities ceased to exist on that date. The contracts subsisted as long as the Insurance Company worked but the payments were postponed till the condition about actuarial surplus was fulfilled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contracts remained in force as contingent liabilities despite no surplus; s.9 substitutes Corporation unless expressly provided otherwise, no such provision exists unlike ss.14,15,36.

holdings.text: The word 'surplus' in the deposit undertakings, Controller's letter, and Section 28 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act has a technical meaning referring to actuarial valuation surplus as defined under the Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: We accept this argument. The word surplus here has the technical meaning which arises from the Insurance Act which is made applicable for purposes of valuation by s. 43 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act read with Notification No. G.S.R. 734 dated August 23, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Technical meaning from Insurance Act forms and schedules applied via s.26 and s.43 LIC Act; accepts petitioner's contention distinguishing from ordinary surplus assets.

holdings.text: Section 28 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act does not bar or preclude payment of the deposits from the Corporation's actuarial surplus.

anchor.surface_text: The two sections must be read harmoniously and it could not have been intended that s. 28 was to be used to negative what s. 9 provided so explicitly. We think that on this harmonious construction we must hold that s. 28 does not put any bar in the way of the Corporation in the fulfilment of its obligations arising under s. 9.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 discretionary regarding remainder surplus after 95% to policyholders; Government directions expected to respect s.9 liabilities; no peremptory override of s.9.

holdings.text: Sections 9 and 28 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act must be read harmoniously, with s.28 controlled by and not negativing the explicit obligations under s.9.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, s. 9 is so compulsive in its wording that s. 28 which is discretionary, at least so far as the Central Government is concerned, may be taken to be controlled by the former. The two sections must be read harmoniously

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 explicit and compulsive; s.28 discretionary; legislature could not intend s.28 to defeat s.9; harmonious reading preserves both.

holdings.text: The question of whether Section 28 is ultra vires Articles 19 and 31 does not arise as it does not override s.9 and is not peremptory in defeating s.9 claims.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. V. Gupte, the learned Solicitor-General, who appeared on behalf of the Government of India, contended that s. 28 was not ultra vires the Constitution... That question cannot, however, arise because we agree with him that there is nothing peremptory in the latter part of s. 28

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide constitutionality since s.28 read harmoniously does not deprive property without compensation or override s.9; apprehension well-founded but hypothetical.

outcome.relief_summary: Life Insurance Corporation's appeal rejected; contracts binding under s.9 LIC Act, repayable from actuarial valuation surplus of Corporation; s.28 does not bar fulfilment of obligations.

anchor.surface_text: It is wrong to contend that as the Insurance Company had nosurplus in its hand on September 1, 1956, its contingent liabilities ceased to exist on that date. The contracts subsisted as long as the Insurance Company worked but the payments were postponed till the condition about actuarial surplus was fulfilled.

It is wrong to contend that as the Insurance Company had nosurplus in its hand on September 1, 1956, its contingent liabilities ceased to exist on that date. anchor.surface_text: We accept this argument. The word surplus here has the technical meaning which arises from the Insurance Act which is made applicable for purposes of valuation by s. 43 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act read with Notification No. G.S.R. 734 dated August 23, 1958.

edges.explanation: h3 directly holds Section 28 does not bar payment, addressing i2

anchor.surface_text: The two sections must be read harmoniously and it could not have been intended that s. 28 was to be used to negative what s. 9 provided so explicitly. We think that on this harmonious construction we must hold that s. 28 does not put any bar in the way of the Corporation in the fulfilment of its obligations arising under s. 9.

The two sections must be read harmoniously and it could not have been intended that s. 28 was to be used to negative what s. 9 provided so explicitly. We think that on this harmonious construction we must hold that s. 28 does not put any bar in the way of the Corporation in the fulfilment of its obligations arising under s. 9.
